message:
After 4 attempts, the final being upgrading  Virtualbox to the most recent version, I guess things are not looking good for Windows 10, the OS that is supposed to run on many devices.

Of course this is not just a Windows bashing post, so anyone who knows how to get this to work, please enlighten me with your abundant knowledge :)

data.message: It might be a Virtualbox problem, because I've been using the previews for a long time (since november) and haven't faced any critical problems since then (no blue screens), and I've been upgrading from one preview to the other every few weeks and didn't lose any data :)
I don't think so, because I am using the latest version of virtualbox with the latest update

maybe Windows 10 boots differently, and thus you might need a future version of Virtualbox.
Or maybe Windows 10 has a few bugs that relate to virtualization that are yet to be fixed.

Could you possibly try using vmware workstation v10 or v11?
I have the technical preview running well on it
Guys the idea is that this is supposed to be a cool OS that can run on multiple devices, it certainly hasn't done this so far

I have encountered a couple of bugs. But not something really serious like urs. I think that's the idea behind a technical preview. Perhaps it's got something to do with the HDD settings in "VirtualBox". Try switching between AHCI and IDE.

Well a VM isn't really a device, it's more like a trick :D
But anyways, I think it has happened before where VM software needed an update to support a certain OS, I remember Parallels on Mac needed an update to support Windows 8, so this isn't a new thing.

the point is I can grab any old or new OS off the internet and install it in 5 mins, Windows cannot do that. Also, Windows is 3.5 GB while the biggest linux OS with bells and whistles won't exceed 1.5 GB. The main Windows differentiator long ago was ease of use and compatibility, now that that is gone, I don't expect a bright future for Windows 10. In fact, I make a bold prediction that the next Windows will be Linux based ...

Well if you insist on being extremely biased like that then go ahead and install your beautiful bug-free Linux, ta3eb nafsak 3ala eeh ya3ni badam keda keda what you believe will always be the same no matter what we say? :D
I am talking about real world experience here, not biased emotions. P.S. I used Windows since 1991 so I guess that would make me an expert :)

Also, after trying both, these are my findings. They said an OS for all devices. I used to give Linux a really hard time back in 93 when it was a very basic UI and mostly command line. I remember a Linux guru friend of mine who showed me the first apt-get install when we were using a dial up modem :)

If you've been using Windows for the previous years then you should know what technical preview means, you don't sound like someone who tried Windows 8 developer preview and saw how horrible it was back then :D

man, I tried Windows Vista prerelease, I can't imagine anything worse than that. Anyway, the point is not the war stories here, after installing latest Virtualbox, is there anything else I can do besides hate Windows?
Wait till Windows 10 is released at the end of this month, then go to VirtualBox's forums and see if there are patches that need to be done to make it work, if not then try installing it again :)
:) Yeah, I won't be waiting, I have no reason to. The thing is, if they release a preview, they could at least test it on the environment that it will most likely be installed i.e. Virtualbox :)

Or do what I did, get a very old PC, put an SSD in it, and try Windows 10 preview in it, and be ready to see the start menu crash every few days, I'm on build 10130, they fixed must of the start menu issues but there are still a few of them that will probably be fixed by the end of the month.
And BTW it seems that it works on VMWare (according to Ahmed Ahmed) which as far as I know is much better than VirtualBox, so you can try that too
even the most unstable versions of Linux are more stable than that. And the start menu isn't really what I was watching for, rather memory footprint and performance. Oh, well.

Performance in preview build is very bad because you are running debug builds that logs everything and sends it back to Microsoft automatically and you can't disable that because that's why they let people try the previews.
know, the thing is, unstable, untested. That's bad even for a tech preview
Anyway, thanks for your time Hassan Aly Selim, you've been a champ, if you find out anything new please ping me :)
I'm not sure if you read all the things I wrote :D

Hassan Aly Selim I understand you, but I urge you to try some early release linux on Virtualbox and compare that experience, then you will understand why I find the quality poor. You see, if you build quality into your lifecycle at all stages, the output will always be high quality, quality is not something you put at the very end of the cycle. Reference Agile, Lean, TDD ...etc
